awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Stretchability by Design - Understanding Mechanical Phenomena in Microarchitectured Soft Material Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) program will investigate mechanical phenomena in microarchitectured soft materials such as conjugated polymers to achieve stretchability by design and thereby stable device performance under large stresses. Conjugated polymers are considered as the basic material for organic semiconductors, which are used for various electronic material systems and sensing devices for applications in energy, healthcare, biomedical, civil, mechanical, aerospace, and chemical engineering. However, conjugated polymers are not stretchable. While generally flexible, their stretchability is restricted up to a few percent. At large deformations, cracks can deteriorate electronic device performance. This weakness limits their use in industrial applications that require large stretchability and new applications demanding complete flexibility. Society will benefit from new methods to predict material properties via mechanics-driven simulations for use in flexible hybrid electronics. The award will create science, technology, engineering, and mathematics opportunities for high school to graduate students in microarchitectured material design and macroarchitectured sustainable systems, and will impact on diversity by reducing barriers of first generation college students to pursue an engineering degree.

Currently, no theory reliably predicts all the complex interactions and non-equilibrium mechanisms arising during instability-induced phase separation of polymer blends, being a promising technique to increase stretchability in soft material systems. Nor is there a theory to predict failure behavior of the resulting conjugated/amorphous polymer blend material and the large deformation those materials must withstand in flexible hybrid electronics applications. The wide range of length and time scales of those mechanisms results in simulations merely able to capture experimentally observed phenomena in a qualitative way. This project aims to close this gap by an integrated theoretical, computational, and experimental approach. The astonishing advancements of theoretical mechanics, high-performance computational resources, and experimental testing and visualization techniques, make this award particularly timely. This research will contribute to developing computational scale bridging techniques to predict, quantitatively, the effect of varying polymer, solvent, and substrate properties, blend ratios, or evaporation rates on induced instabilities, blend morphologies, nanoconfined polymer properties, and failure mechanisms in polymer blends.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project was to gain a mechanics-based understanding of how microstructural design in polymer based soft materials enables tunable modifications of their stretchability up to failure. Conjugated polymers are the basic material for organic semiconductors in organic electronics. While generally flexible, they are stretchable only up to a few percent. At large deformations, cracks appear that often significantly deteriorate the performance of electronic devices. This weakness limits the use of conjugated polymers in industrial applications that require large stretchability, and new applications that demand complete flexibility. In this project, an integrated research between theory, computations, and experiments was performed for soft material systems and applications in the field of wearable electronic devices. 

Of particular importance are morphological instabilities, which play a crucial role in the behavior of advanced engineering applications made of soft matter. Such instabilities initiate when a thin stiff film on a compliant substrate is subject to compressive stresses. For bilayer systems, the first mode of instability is sinusoidal wrinkling. While the critical conditions to induce wrinkling are extensively studied, the more complex patterns formed beyond wrinkling remain elusive and poorly understood. A generic computational framework capable of capturing various instabilities, using isogeometric analysis enhanced with a concurrent eigenvalue analysis was proposed. It was shown that the eigenvalue analysis provides quantitatively accurate predictions for the onset of instabilities and that the isogeometric formulation furnishes significantly more accurate results compared to standard finite elements. This approach was extended to hydrogel based systems, which, under a variety of external stimuli, can undergo coupled solid deformation and fluid diffusion and exhibit large volume changes. Stability diagrams showed that the short-time response of hydrogels immersed in water is highly unstable. This was further extended through a combined computational and experimental approach by looking at two dissimilar hydrogel layers bonded together which become unstable when the compressive stresses due to diffusion-driven swelling of the layers reach a critical point and creases form at the interface. It was shown that both the equilibrium and the transient characteristics of interface creases can be tuned by controlling the material properties, in contrast to the reported material-independent behavior of creases in elastomers. In agreement with experimental observations of swelling bilayer hydrogels, the presented computational results demonstrated that the formation of creases is energetically more favorable than wrinkle formation at the interface. These results were further extended to investigate instabilities also in biological systems. 

As the understanding of crystallization and failure onset in polymer systems aids to understanding limitations in applications such as wearables, a multi-scale polymer network model to capture strain induced crystallization in rubber-like polymeric materials was proposed. At the microscopic scale, a new chain formulation was presented by studying the thermodynamic behavior of a polymer chain and its crystallization mechanism inside a stretching polymer network, which was then upscaled based on a maximal advance path multiscale computational framework that predicts the experimentally observed anisotropic crystallization of rubber-like materials. Since strain-induced crystallization further contributes to the fracture toughness of certain rubbers, a criterion based on internal bond energy, incorporating the effects of crystallization to predict fracture initiation in polymers with pre-existing cracks was developed for characterizing the behavior of rubber when subjected to both uniaxial and biaxial deformation states. 

These theoretical and computational results proved essential in applying the gained understanding to soft and conformable wearable electronics. Those require stretchable semiconductors, but existing ones typically sacrifice charge transport mobility to achieve stretchability. In collaboration with experimentalists, a concept based on the nanoconfinement of polymers to substantially improve the stretchability of polymer semiconductors, without affecting charge transport mobility, was explored. The increased polymer chain dynamics under nanoconfinement significantly reduced the modulus of the conjugated polymer and largely delayed the onset of crack formation under strain. Subsequently, a highly stretchable conducting polymer, was realized with a range of enhancers that change morphology and act as conductivity-enhancing dopants. Ultra-lightweight strain- and strain-rate-invariant conductance in a stretchable and compressible 3D conducting polymer foam and a 3D structuring approach toward strain-accommodating, biocompliant conductors was achieved. Finally, strain-insensitive intrinsically stretchable transistors and circuits were created in an collaborative effort. 

In addition to generating scientific impact through a gained understanding of new physical phenomena in microstructured soft material systems and the development of computational multiscale methods of intellectual merit, a robust education plan was tightly integrated into the project research in a variety of creative ways to impact students from high school through graduate school, and high school teachers. Lessons were taught in a neighborhood school with a large number of students typically underrepresented in higher eduction, a high school teacher was hosted during summer months, and an undergraduate student from an underrepresented background was hosted during another summer quarter. Several former graduate students who worked on the this project are now Professors at leading universities in the US.

 


Last Modified: 10/25/2021
Modified by: Christian Linder
